chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: Rackspace Auto Scale is an API-based tool that automatically scales resources in response to an increase or decrease in overall workload based on user-defined thresholds.

Create servers by using Cloud Servers. For more information, see the Next Generation Cloud Servers™ Developer Guide.
Create load balancers by using Cloud Load Balancers. For more information see the Rackspace Cloud Load Balancers Developers Guide.

chapter.title: Core Concepts
chapter.para: Rackspace &PROD; is an API-based tool that automatically scales resources in response to an increase or decrease in overall workload based on user-defined thresholds.

&PROD; functions by linking these services:
Rackspace Cloud Monitoring. For more information, read the Rackspace Cloud Monitoring Getting Started Guide.
&PROD; API
Load-balanced Cloud Servers. For more information, read the Rackspace Load Balancers Getting Started Guide.
You can set up a schedule for launching Auto Scale or define an event that is triggered by Cloud Monitoring. You can also specify a minimum and maximum number of cloud servers, the amount of resources you want to increase or decrease and the thresholds in Cloud Monitoring that triggers the scaling activities.

section.title: Auto Scale Process
section.para: There are two ways to configure Auto Scale:

note.para: &PROD; does not configure any information within a server. You must configure your services to function properly when each server is started. We recommend automating your servers' startup processes with Chef or a similar tool.

section.title: Schedule-based Configuration
section.para: You can configure Auto Scale to be triggered based on a user-defined schedule that is specified in one or more policies.

This configuration option is helpful if you know that your Cloud Server deployment will need additional resources during certain peak times. For example, if you need additional server resources during the weekend, you can define a policy that adds 50 servers on Friday evening and then removes these servers again on Sunday evening to return to a regular operational state.
The following diagram outlines how Scaling by Schedule works:

note.para: The schedule-based configuration option does not require Cloud Monitoring to be set up.

section.title: Monitoring-based configuration
section.para: You can configure Auto Scale to be triggered based on a predefined alarm or threshold that has been previously set up in Cloud Monitoring.
Monitoring-based configuration works the following way:

listitem.para: In Cloud Monitoring, you configure alarms that are triggered when a high utilization of resources occurs.
When Cloud Monitoring sets off an alarm for high utilization of resources within a group, a webhook is triggered.

The webhook launches the Rackspace Auto Scale service, which looks up the policy that has been defined in accordance with the webhook. This policy determines the amount of cloud servers that need to be added or removed in case the alarm is triggered.

section.title: Webhooks
section.para: Auto Scale uses webhooks to initiate a scaling event. A webhook is an industry-standard protocol for sending events between systems. A webhook consists of an HTTP callback that is triggered by some user-defined event, such as an alarm that is set through Cloud Monitoring. When that event occurs the source site makes an HTTP request to the URI configured for the webhook.

A webhook contains a POST call to a defined URL, potentially with a payload in the POST body. You can send webhooks with a simple call using whatever library is available for your environment. You can also manually send them via cURL.
The following example shows how to send a webhook with cURL:
For more information about how webhooks are used in the Rackspace API, see
http://docs.rackspace.com/cm/api/v1.0/cm-devguide/content/service-notification-types-crud.html#service-notification-types-webhook.

Auto Scale also support anonymous webhooks. In regular webhooks, the {capability_version}/{capability_hash} is specified by URL. In anonymous webhooks, the URL is replaced with a hash that is known only to the issuer—this is the reason why the webhook is called "anonymous" because no authentication is needed.

section.title: Cooldowns
section.para: Auto Scale supports a cooldown feature. A cooldown is a configured period of time that must pass between actions. By configuring group cooldowns, you control how often a group can have a policy applied, which can help servers scaling up to complete the scale up before another policy is executed. By configuring policy cooldowns, you control how often a policy can be executed, which can help provide quick scale-ups and gradual scale-downs.

Cooldowns work the following way:
Cooldowns allow some time for the initial scaling response to take effect, potentially resolving the situation that triggered the policy. When a scaling policy is triggered, cooldown periods begin for both the scaling policy and the group.
While the cooldown is active, any additional requests to the group or to the specific policy are ignored.
After the cooldown period ends, if Cloud Monitoring still detects the situation that triggered the initial scaling activity, another alarm triggers another round of scaling activity.
When a group of servers are being automatically managed by AutoScale, you may need to set limits as to how the group changes over time. Cooldowns allow you to control the rate of change of a group. A cooldown is a configured period of time that must pass between actions. Group cooldowns control how often a group can be modified by denying all policy executions until the cooldown expires. Policy cooldowns control how often a single specific policy can be executed. For example, a policy cooldown can require at least six hours until any successive scale down policies are reactivated. This allows you to "Scale up fast, scale down slow."

section.para: The scaling group configuration specifies the basic elements of the Auto Scale configuration. It manages how many servers can participate in the scaling group. It also specifies information related to load balancers.

section.para: Scaling group policies specify how to modify the scaling group and its behavior. You can specify multiple policies to manage a scaling group.
Scaling policies specify the following:

tr.td: Specifies the change value, in incremental stages or per cent.
Specifies the policy cooldown time, in seconds.
Specifies how the policy will be executed (by webhook or based on a schedule.

section.para: You have several options for defining an Auto Scale policy:

listitem.para: Define a policy that triggers Auto Scale activities through a webhook.
Define a policy that triggers Auto Scale activities based on a schedule.

section.title: Webhook-triggered policies
section.para: You can define a scaling policy that is invoked by a webhook when a predefined event occurs. To configure a webhook-based policy, you need to set the type parameter to "webhook" and then provide the following information:

tr.td: Specifies the number of entities to add or remove, for example "1" implies that 1 server needs to be added.
Specifies the change value, in incremental stages or per cent.
Specifies final capacity that is desired by the scale up event

section.title: Schedule-based Policies
section.para: You can define a scaling policy that is invoked by a preset schedule. To configure a schedule-based policy, you need to set the type parameter to "schedule" and then provide the following information:

tr.td: Specifies the number of entities to add or remove, for example "1" implies that 1 server needs to be added.
Specifies the change value, in incremental stages or per cent.
Specifies final capacity that is desired by the scale up event
Provide information related to the time when the policy is supposed to be invoked.

section.title: Scaling by Percentage
section.para: You can define a policy that scales your server resources up and down by a predefined percentage. For example, you can define a policy to increase your resources by 20% if a certain event predefined event occurs.
The following diagram outlines how scaling by percentage works.

section.title: Using the Min and Max Values with Policies
section.para: When setting up the configuration for your scaling groups, you configure the minimum and maximum amount of resources that are allowed in your configuration. These values are specified in the minEntities and maxEntities parameters under GroupConfiguration, and are invoked whenever you update your group configuration.

important.para: If the amount of resources that is specified in a policy differs from the amount that is specified under GroupConfiguration, the preconfigured values take precedence.

section.para: The following diagram illustrates how the min and max values work in a scaling scenario.

section.title: Deleting Resources
section.para: You can set a policy to specify when you want some of your resources deleted, and how many resources should be deleted.
When deleting servers, Auto Scale follows these rules:

listitem.para: If there are no new servers that are in the process of being built, the oldest servers are deleted first.
If there are new servers that are in the process of being built and in a "pending" state, these servers are deleted first.

section.title: Authenticate
section.para: As with all Rackspace APIs, before you can use the Auto Scale API you must authenticate with your Rackspace credentials.

listitem.para: When you authenticate, you submit your credentials to the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service.
If your credentials are valid, the Identity Service responds with your Service Catalog, which includes your token, token ID, user ID, and token tenant ID.
To make requests of &PROD;, you must use your token tenant ID, also known as the tenantID.

section.para: If you subscribe to many Rackspace services, your Service Catalog response might be lengthy. For an example of an annotated Service Catalog response, showing how to recognize the token and other elements in both JSON and XML formats, see http://docs.rackspace.com/auth/api/v2.0/auth-client-devguide/content/Sample_Request_Response-d1e64.html.
After you have your token, you can use it to identify yourself to &PRODNAME; and other services.

tip.para: For detailed information about the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service, visit http://docs.rackspace.com/auth/api/v2.0/auth-client-devguide/content/QuickStart-000.html.

section.para: To authenticate access to Rackspace Cloud services, you issue an authentication request to the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service, which is an implementation of the OpenStack Keystone Identity Service v2.0.
Auto Scale supports Role-based Access Control (RBAC) for more information, read the Permissions Matrix for Auto Scale article on the Knowledge Center.

important.para: Multiple Rackspace Cloud Identity Service endpoints exist. You may use any endpoint, regardless of where your account was created.

section.title: Save an Image
section.para: After authenticating to the Web service you create a cloud server using one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Create a server through the Control Panel.
Create a server through the Cloud Servers API by using a Create Server request.

note.para: Auto Scale does not use the name parameter in the Create Server request, as the server name is automatically generate.
The metadata parameter is optional. The maximum size of the metadata key and value is 255 bytes each. For more information, see the Server Metadata documentation.

section.para:
With the Cloud Servers API, you can use a List Images request to retrieve a list of options available for configuring your server. Requesting a List of Cloud Server Images
The following example shows how to request a list cloud server images. $ curl -X GET \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -H "X-Auth-token:{auth-token}" \ https://ord.servers.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2/{tenant-id}/images?type=SNAPSHOT | python -mjson.tool

After creating your server you customize it so that it can process your requests. For example, if you are building a webhead scaling group, configure Apache to start on launch and serve the files that you need.
After you have created and customized your server, save its image and record the imageID value that is returned in the response body.

section.title: Delete a Scaling Group
section.para: You can use the Auto Scale API to deactivate and delete one or more scaling groups. Your options for deleting the scaling group depend on whether your scaling group has active entities or not.

note.para: You cannot delete a scaling group when it has active entities associated with it.

section.para: When a group contains no servers, you can eliminate the group by sending a DELETE request to its group ID.
The following three options are possible for deleting a scaling group:

listitem.para: If there are no active entities in your configuration, use the DELETE request to delete the scaling group.
If there are active entities in your configuration, update your scaling group configuration by submitting a PUT request and setting the minEntities and maxEntities parameters to 0.
Force the deletion of your group by submitting a DELETE request and setting the force parameter to true.

Submit a DELETE request with the tenantId and groupId parameters specified in the request URL:

example.title: Delete a Scaling Group using Force Delete
example.para: The Auto Scale API provides an option for users to force delete a scaling group that has active servers. The Force Delete option will remove all servers in the configuration from the load balancer(s) and then delete the server.

warning.para: Using Force Delete will remove all servers that are associated with the scaling group immediately. Users are discouraged from using the Force Delete option and to manually delete servers instead.

example.para: To use the Force Delete option, submit a DELETE request with the tenantId and groupId parameters specified in the request URL, and set the force parameter to true.

Upon successful submission of this request the minEntities and maxEntities parameters will automatically be set to 0 and the deletion of the group will begin. If the DELETE request is successful, a 204 response code with an empty response body will be returned.
